Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
1055358 (CAREER)
Xingwei (Vivian) Wang
University of Massachusetts, Lowell
CAREER: Novel Mechanism for Generation and Receiving of Ultrasound on a Single Fiber Using Nanoparticles

The goal of this CARRER research is to investigate and create a novel mechanism to systematically integrate an ultrasound receiving module and a generation module using nanoparticles into a single optical fiber so that it can steer the ultrasound to any desired direction.

Intellectual Merit:

1) The fundamental research will strive to eliminate the critical constraint, low efficiency, which has been restricting the practical applications of the optical fiber ultrasound generators.
2) The outcome of this research will open up a new avenue for research on integration of ultrasound generation and receiving on a single optical fiber tip.
3) The research will be the first attempt to optically steer the direction of ultrasound generated in an optical fiber which can allow fast 360-degree cross section view and defect detection in any angle.

Broader Impacts:

1) The fundamental research will have a direct impact on the creation of the world?s smallest duplex ultrasound probe. The probe can be used for diagnosis of coronary artery disease which is the No. 1 killer in USA. It can assess the stent effectiveness and diagnose misplacement of stents which occurs in 66.5% of the 1 million coronary artery disease patients each year. Other applications include structural health monitoring, surveillance in unmanned miniature vehicles, and navigation in autonomous intelligence robotics. 2) Educational initiatives will broaden participation of the underrepresented groups, especially female students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funding enabled our group to conduct research and experiments aiming at creating a novel mechanism to systematically integrate an ultrasound receiving module and a generation module using nanoparticles. The project was funded from July, 2011 to June, 2016 and then went through a one-year no cost extension.

An enhanced understanding of the all-optical ultrasonic technology has potential to significantly impact broad areas. The knowledge can guide the development of a new generation of ultrasonic probes for echography. Spectral analysis of in vivo tissues, coronary arteries, skin tumors, prostate by conventional piezoelectric transducers couldf all be replaced with the all-optical methods providing better performance. In addition, miniature size has been pursued in applications where limited space is available, such as ultrasound navigation systems in autonomous intelligence robotics/bio-mimic systems, and surveillance systems in unmanned miniature vehicles. The all-optical approach is desired when the environments are chemically or electrically hazardous, or in high temperature conditions, for example, real-time structural health monitoring and material characterization in harsh environments. Finally, the optical probe can also work in strong magnetic or electrical environments (e.g. near magnetic resonant imaging [MRI] machine) where the electrical counterparts cannot.

Fiber optic photoacoustic ultrasound generators was first achieved by coating gold nanocomposite on the tip, and was verified by a faster nanosecond laser. The bandwidth was increased to more than 20 MHz after applying the faster nanosecond laser.

Two applications were explored by using these fiber optic ultrasound generatorst. The first application was to use it to obtain the ultrasound image of a pork slide. The other application was to use it to characterize the PDMS films by interrogating the resonant frequencies. In the first application, the pork slice was scanned with a step of 100 μm. The fat tissue and the muscle tissue could be differentiated clearly. This application has demonstrated that the fiber optic ultrasound generator has great potential in medical applications. In the second application, the PDMS films were characterized by an all-optical approach, which illustrated the system’s capability of characterizing biological films through resonant frequencies. This demonstrates another potential application of the technique.

Then the fiber optic ultrasound generator was fully characterized. The energy conversion efficiency has been calculated and has significantly increased when compared with the one using aluminum (by 5 orders of magnitude) or epoxy mixed with graphite (1000 times higher). Moreover, the ultrasound distribution around the generator has been obtained. The generator showed a focal profile of the ultrasound distribution. B-mode ultrasound imaging has been obtained by using a chicken wing as the target. The fiber optic ultrasound generator and the hydrophone were mounted on a 2D moving stage to scan through the chicken wing. Successfully obtaining the ultrasound image demonstrated the capability of using a fiber optic ultrasound generator to produce ultrasound images.

A single-mode fiber, dip coated with gold nanocomposite, was proven to be able to not only generate but also to receive ultrasound signals. This presented an easy method to manufacture an ultrasound probe, which can be used in harsh and restrictive environments.

The series of experiments have validated the structure, gold nano-composite on the tip of a single-mode fiber’s ability of generating and receiving ultrasound signal. It also led to a better understanding of the photoacoustic mechanism and addressed the low generation efficiency which was the major drawback of the previous photoacoustic technology.
